tags: this comes from a former dany opposite
summary: in a way, it’s the battle of the bastards plot line all over again. seeing jon snow doing impulsive things when sansa warned him...
body:
in a way, it’s the battle of the bastards plot line all over again. seeing jon snow doing impulsive things when sansa warned him and then observing him succeed despite that because of sansa’s sacrifice to ask littlefinger for help (which by the way, expected something back from her) , only to see jon being praised by everyone just because he has a dick and was raised to know how to physically fight a battle. how is that different from jon being only just as competent as dany during the fight of the dawn and hearing him being praised to high heavens for the things daenerys was doing since much longer than him. of course daenerys doesn’t want him to reveal anything, of course she will want to protect her claim. it has been her life’s mission to sit on that damn throne! she doesn’t have anything else, and here comes “small pecker” to steal it all away from her. 

there’s no way i can excuse the writers decision of repeating injustice after injustice towards female characters without acknowledging the inherent bias in rewarding jon’s passiveness of not wanting but still getting everything sansa and daenerys have worked their butts off to win.

tags: hate her all you want but dont pretend like shes villain just to prop up your faves
summary: I’m tired of people saying that sansa is turning into cersei or baelish just because she has learnt things from them. she’s NOT...
body:
I’m tired of people saying that sansa is turning into cersei or baelish just because she has learnt things from them. she’s NOT like them nor will she ever be because her overall intentions are good and are not completely selfish. Sansa Stark is not a villain. She knows how to play the game but does so without losing her humanity. She’s smart, politically skilled and has learnt how to manipulate to survive. She watched her family die for always doing what was right while people like Baelish and Cersei survived by doing immoral things. She’s learnt from everyone who she’s been around in her life and that includes people like Cersei and Baelish but learning how to survive from them does not at all mean she is like them or will become them.

also on another note it makes me really uncomfortable when people compare a victim to their abusers unless the victim themselves is an abuser.

summary: I know a lot of us were disappointed to not get the girl's reactions to rlj but (much as I hate it with the passion of a...
question: I know a lot of us were disappointed to not get the girl's reactions to rlj but (much as I hate it with the passion of a thousand suns and almost as much as I hate not getting Jon's full reaction to it), I have to believe there was more discussed after the scene ended.  We got Sansa being emotional after but what about Arya?  Why was she so chill heading off to KL after learning 'Jon will want me even if no one else does' is not her brother? I just don't think we're getting the full picture :/
answer:
I agree. I of course which we would have gotten a reaction of the Stark sisters but there would have been a major difference between Sansa and Arya if we were. It might have been too obvious had they done this because Arya would have probably hugged Jon and assured him he is always her brother but Sansa…Sansa would have taken the news that probably would have left her standing there completely shocked.

It’s a good point that in the aftermath of the reveal Arya really doesn’t seem to care all that much and is going off to finish her business with Cersei. While Sansa is only alone on the Battlements staring up at the dragons and when Tyrion comes up she only asks “Why her?” If Jon knew of his parentage, if he knew they could be together, why her? Why Daenerys? She looked so pained in that scene and could hardly keep it together for Tyrion. She even had to compose herself before she could look at Tyrion and we see she desperately does not want Jon to leave no matter how Tyrion tries to spin it. The girl is in love y’all.

summary: Ok, I am DONE with people saying Dany is “Mad”. And this is coming from a Sansa Stan. Why is she mad? Because she has given...
body: Ok, I am DONE with people saying Dany is “Mad”. And this is coming from a Sansa Stan. Why is she mad? Because she has given everything she has to a bunch of people who will give her nothing in return and still look down on her? Because she is angry that her “advisors” have lost her everything? Because her children and best friend have all been killed right before her eyes. Because no matter what she does, a cock makes someone better than she is? Let’s put it this way. Do you consider Tywin Lannister mad? He had his soldiers attack Kings Landing and slaughter and rape everyone. He instructed the Mountain to slaughter babies as they slept. When Tyrion was captured he had the Mountain go to the villages in the Riverlands and destroy towns of innocent people. The list goes on. But what does everyone call him? Cunning, merciless, ruthless, a badass. A bad guy, sure, but nobody ever questions his sanity. So why, again, is Dany mad? Because she’s arrogant? So is Sansa. And I LOVE Sansa. But I also love Daenerys. So why, when a woman, (who mind you, has always been TRYING to do good, even if it didn’t go well) does something like want revenge, her sanity is put into question. I mean I know why, but I need everyone else to understand why. I’m not saying it’s right to burn a city, what I’m saying is Dany is angry and hurt and alone and has every right to feel the emotions she is feeling. I’m sick of every time a female character shows anything beyond docile and kind, she is a “Crazy bitch”. (Unless of course you show masculine traits, but that’s a whole different post).

summary: On Sunday, when my dad watched Rhaegal’s body fall into the ocean, he said “Yes.... take the dragon and let Theon rise from the...
body:
On Sunday, when my dad watched Rhaegal’s body fall into the ocean, he said “Yes…. take the dragon and let Theon rise from the sea.”

I have now spent the last two days trying to figure out if Sansa’s tears, the funeral pyre, and Rhaegal bleeding as he flies through the sky count as salt and smoke and a bleeding star.

“[A] hero reborn in the sea.”

summary: Why would Sansa be jealous of Dany's power when she already has more? Sansa is now the LoWF, Head of House Stark, and de facto...
question: Why would Sansa be jealous of Dany's power when she already has more? Sansa is now the LoWF, Head of House Stark, and de facto QintN. She has allies in the Vale, Riverlands, and possibly the Iron Islands. Meanwhile, Dany is merely a queen claimant/conqueror whose forces and dragons have been severely reduced in a matter of days. Even her own advisers are turning from her. No, Sansa is jealous, but it's because of Jon.
answer:
I’ve been told by at least 2 Dany stans today that Sansa is jealous of Daenerys power because she wants it for herself. Considering Jon is the one shown in the middle of them, he keeps being brought up in their conversations, it is Jon she’s worried about, it is Jon who Daenerys is taking away, and Jon who could be in love with Daenerys, it’s clear to me what she’s truly jealous of.

There’s nothing Sansa needs to be jealous of. As you said, she’s a well respected and loved ruler by her people. She has the backings of the Riverlands, Vale, and the North. Allies that she has earned their respect. Daenerys power is resting on fear and that’s a feeble foundation to build on. Now, she could burn down KL and even if she does somehow sit the Throne it won’t be for long because if they hated Cersei, they will hate Daenerys far more who proved herself to be the Mad King’s daughter.

There’s nothing Sansa needs to be jealous of. As you said, she’s a well respected and loved ruler by her people. She has the backings of the Riverlands, Vale, and the North. Allies that she has earned their respect. Daenerys power is resting on fear and that’s a feeble foundation to build on. Now, she could burn down KL and even if she does somehow sit the Throne it won’t be for long because if they hated Cersei, they will hate Daenerys far more who proved herself to be the Mad King’s daughter.

summary: It's disturbing that the asoiaf fandom uses the 'stop projecting your modern sensibilities unto these characters. This is a...
body: It’s disturbing that the asoiaf fandom uses the ‘stop projecting your modern sensibilities unto these characters. This is a medieval setting’ in order to justify the violence the male characters perpetuate towards women, but never when it comes to Sansa and Catelyn and their lack of agency in the story. Sansa and Catelyn are noble women and that makes their actions in these books understandable.

#westeros appreciation | requests: open

summary: may 7th — late bloomer
body:
may 7th — late bloomer

characters: sansa stark, tyrion lannister

relationship: sansa stark/tyrion lannister

warnings: minor ptsd/trauma flashbacks

notes: au, set post-finale where sansa moves to the rock with tyrion, whom she remarried. westeros is ruled by a council, with members including bran (the head and current lord of winterfell), sam, davos, tyrion, etc.

For a few days, Sansa waited at Casterly Rock alone as her lord husband was with the new Council, meeting at the Dragonpit. It was like that every month, where for a few days Tyrion would have to leave and meet up with the newly-formed government in Westeros, where men from all the kingdoms discussed issues and affairs under the watchful eyes of her brother, Bran.

While she practiced needlework in their shared bedroom, a handmaiden walked in. “Lord Tyrion has just arrived back,” she spoke quickly, almost flustered. Sansa looked up from her newest design and nodded.

“I’ll come see to him. Thank you.” Her manners always got the best of her, and her husband always remarked on it before they went to bed. “You don’t have to say “please” and “thank you” to the servants,” he’d say, smiling and laughing. She always giggled along, but her mannerisms never seemed to change.

She turned her head to look out their window, accessible from her velvet-colored chair, and noticed a group of horses entering the gates of the Rock. Quickly, Sansa changed herself into a red and gold dress, letting her hair flow down in soft curls. When she finished, she left the room and moved down the long lengths of stairs, hoping to reach her lord husband before he began his hike all the way up.

It took her a bit, but she did get down to him first. Tyrion waited by the doorway, talking with a few of his guards. She exhaled in relief, glad he wasn’t arguing, for then her entrance would be unfortunate. As she took a few slow steps, Sansa realized how her shoes made only soft sounds. He wasn’t going to hear her. Instead, she spoke, “My lord husband.”

Tyrion handed one of the other men a scroll, turning to face Sansa. “My lady wife.” She could see him clear his throat. “You look radiant.”

“I’m glad you’re home.” Home. The word seemed so foreign as she looked around. Winterfell was her real home, not the Rock! Yet, some feeling made her stomach flutter everytime she heard the place aloud. Casterly Rock.

As she climbed down the steps to meet him, he moved forwards to her. She wanted to reach down and cup his face with her hands, to press her lips to his own or even to his forehead. Sansa supposed it was just the fact that they had been gone for so long that she was so happy, but when she looked at him she felt drunk on his image.

They walked up the stairs together towards their room. Sansa wanted to link their arms, but due to their height difference she didn’t believe it would work. Of course, they held hands and stood close to each other. The time they spent now as husband and wife was much different than when they were married in King’s Landing. “How was the Council? And Bran?”

He looked over the side of the stairs as he ascended with her. “I would have much rather stayed here than leave. Your brother was fine. He’s taking up the position very well.”

“Has he changed much?”

Tyrion shrugged his shoulders, and the two reached a new set of stairs. “He doesn’t have a beard like me, if that’s what you’re implying.” He grinned a bit. “I suppose he seems more interested in current affairs.”

“Bran was always the best of us Starks,” Sansa murmured. She felt her husband squeeze her hand softly. “My lady mother always said so.”

“That’s nonsense,” he affirmed, and internally Sansa beamed with pride. “I can’t vouch for your sister, but I enjoy spending my company with you rather than your brother.”

The two of them made it to the hallway where their room was, and she carefully let go of his hand to smooth out her dress. “You only say that because I’m your wife.”

“And Bran is my superior, so what?” When Sansa moved her hand down to grab his, he took it and pressed it to his lips, causing her to turn to him slightly. “Did I ever tell you how gorgeous you are in that dress?”

“It’s your favorite,” she noted. “I thought it would be a good way to surprise you when you returned home.”

They made it to their room, and Sansa pushed open the door. “It was a good choice.”

Inside, they ate their dinner together as Tyrion went on about the Council. Sansa listened in interest, though she did occasionally drift off and think about his beard, her brother, and sometimes even the bane of her existence, Littlefinger.

When they went to bed, Sansa took longer than her husband to fall asleep. Her dreams had kept her up the nights he was gone, as normally Tyrion would allow his fingers to roam her hair, and she enjoyed his warmth under their furs.

The moon was still high in the sky, and with her eyes closed all Sansa could see was Littlefinger’s begging. She saw the pain and misery in his eyes, and felt guilty. Tyrion heard her whining, mumbling in her sleep. He waited, like he always did, until she started screaming.

“Darling,” he soothed, “Sansa.” She seemed stuck in a dream. Groggily, he prodded at her shoulder.

She mumbled again. You’re a late bloomer, Sansa. You should have realized what I am. I’m evil. I sent you into a marriage you didn’t want, and you failed to realize it sooner. How pathetic. She felt guilty for planning his murder, and yet he taunted her through her thoughts.

“Sansa,” Tyrion repeated, a bit louder. “It’s only a nightmare. Please, wake up.” Her voice faded into a soft murmur, and soon her eyes opened as a cold sweat fell down her face. “Are you alright?”

She let the tears fall from her eyes, and Tyrion was quick to wrap his arms around her body. Sansa sobbed and let her emotions pour out to the Lannister, and he comforted her as he enjoyed doing. When she finally leaned back into the bed, he kept his hands entangled in her hair, and she slowly drifted off into a more peaceful slumber.

Together they would awake, and no one mentioned the night before. It was a silent arrangement: if she wanted to speak about it, she would. Sansa never did.

They ate breakfast together, the Sansa began her needlework while Tyrion began his own tasks as Lord of Casterly Rock. “I would like to go and look at the plants outside today.”

“The Rock isn’t known for its gardens, my lady.” Tyrion was too focused on his work, so he didn’t look up.

Placing down her needles, Sansa got to her feet. The white nightgown she wore clung to her figure, not too tight but just enough to keep her comfortable. “I know, but I think it’s best we get some fresh air.” She used the word “we” to get his attention, and it did the job.

“Alright.”

They walked together, down the stairs hand-in-hand and didn’t speak, but a comfortable silence passed through them. When they arrived outside, a few plants surrounded the entrance to the Rock. Sansa noticed the flowers blooming, all but a small yellow one. “A late bloomer,” she murmured, and thought silently of her dream.

“I told you, our plants aren’t as well-kept as, say, Highgarden.” He watched the yellow flower, just like she did. “Of course, now that Bronn has taken over I’m not so sure those gardens are much better than ours.”

She didn’t respond, and instead pressed two of her fingers to her lips. Slowly, gently, she bent down and pressed the two fingers onto the flower. As she turned to look at him, Tyrion smiled with a fondness and affection he hadn’t shown any other woman before.

Her home was at the Rock now. Sansa enjoyed it.

————————

Inside, they ate their dinner together as Tyrion went on about the Council. Sansa listened in interest, though she did occasionally drift off and think about his beard, her brother, and sometimes even the bane of her existence, Littlefinger.

When they went to bed, Sansa took longer than her husband to fall asleep. Her dreams had kept her up the nights he was gone, as normally Tyrion would allow his fingers to roam her hair, and she enjoyed his warmth under their furs.

The moon was still high in the sky, and with her eyes closed all Sansa could see was Littlefinger’s begging. She saw the pain and misery in his eyes, and felt guilty. Tyrion heard her whining, mumbling in her sleep. He waited, like he always did, until she started screaming.

“Darling,” he soothed, “Sansa.” She seemed stuck in a dream. Groggily, he prodded at her shoulder.

She mumbled again. You’re a late bloomer, Sansa. You should have realized what I am. I’m evil. I sent you into a marriage you didn’t want, and you failed to realize it sooner. How pathetic. She felt guilty for planning his murder, and yet he taunted her through her thoughts.

“Sansa,” Tyrion repeated, a bit louder. “It’s only a nightmare. Please, wake up.” Her voice faded into a soft murmur, and soon her eyes opened as a cold sweat fell down her face. “Are you alright?”

She let the tears fall from her eyes, and Tyrion was quick to wrap his arms around her body. Sansa sobbed and let her emotions pour out to the Lannister, and he comforted her as he enjoyed doing. When she finally leaned back into the bed, he kept his hands entangled in her hair, and she slowly drifted off into a more peaceful slumber.

Together they would awake, and no one mentioned the night before. It was a silent arrangement: if she wanted to speak about it, she would. Sansa never did.

They ate breakfast together, the Sansa began her needlework while Tyrion began his own tasks as Lord of Casterly Rock. “I would like to go and look at the plants outside today.”

“The Rock isn’t known for its gardens, my lady.” Tyrion was too focused on his work, so he didn’t look up.

Placing down her needles, Sansa got to her feet. The white nightgown she wore clung to her figure, not too tight but just enough to keep her comfortable. “I know, but I think it’s best we get some fresh air.” She used the word “we” to get his attention, and it did the job.

“Alright.”

They walked together, down the stairs hand-in-hand and didn’t speak, but a comfortable silence passed through them. When they arrived outside, a few plants surrounded the entrance to the Rock. Sansa noticed the flowers blooming, all but a small yellow one. “A late bloomer,” she murmured, and thought silently of her dream.

“I told you, our plants aren’t as well-kept as, say, Highgarden.” He watched the yellow flower, just like she did. “Of course, now that Bronn has taken over I’m not so sure those gardens are much better than ours.”

She didn’t respond, and instead pressed two of her fingers to her lips. Slowly, gently, she bent down and pressed the two fingers onto the flower. As she turned to look at him, Tyrion smiled with a fondness and affection he hadn’t shown any other woman before.

Her home was at the Rock now. Sansa enjoyed it.

summary: I really want to point out a very big difference, or foil if you want, of Sansa and Danaerys and how they use what they’ve been...
body:
I really want to point out a very big difference, or foil if you want, of Sansa and Danaerys and how they use what they’ve been through.

Sansa never brings up what happened to her with Ramsay unless somebody brings it up first, and that one time she spoke to Littlefinger about what happened to her vividly. She also avoids bringing up her abuse in Kings Landing, and keeps her grief of loosing more than half of her family to herself.

Danaerys, however, takes a much different approach. She speaks about what happened to her, and uses it to her advantage, whether it be to make someone sympathize or feel for her. My biggest example for that is Khal Drogo.

When she’s speaking in a comfortable setting, Danaerys refers to the Khal as her lost love, a husband that was ripped away from her, a man she once treasured and cared for, her “sun and stars”.

However, when she wants to use the Khal to her advatange, she speaks of how she was raped and sold to him.

I just found it interesting how Sansa doesn’t speak of her trauma at all, but when Danaerys does, she uses it to her advantage.

summary: Daenerys victim-shaming Sansa is also another sign about how she doesn't really love Jon or care about his feelings. Does she...
question: Daenerys victim-shaming Sansa is also another sign about how she doesn't really love Jon or care about his feelings. Does she really thinks he wants to be reminded of how his sister/cousin/possible secret love was abused by so many people before they were reunited? I know that Viserys was a creep and she doesn't understand how a healthy family unit works, but surely, she must have thought that would make him sad and angry. Her lack of empathy and general cluelessness is so disturbing.
answer:
Let’s be real, Daenerys didn’t care about Jon or his feelings at all in that entire scene. Once again it is all about her. Her wants, her needs, and her ambitions.

She begs Jon not to tell his family the secret and not once has asked what he might be going through or how he is feeling. She only wants to secure he will not be a threat to her. She talks about how she was envious in the way the people looked and loved Jon the way they never have at her. She stiffens in his arms and tells him that they can only continue on so long as he does what she says. In every scene of Jon and Daenerys even ones that are supposed to be intimate and personal the focus is solely on Daenerys.

And to top it off in that same scene brings up Sansa’s traumas and abuse as a way to sway him to not telling her. Basically, she doesn’t want Jon to trust Sansa and keep him at her side at all times. It’s not that she just doesn’t know about family, she doesn’t care so long as she gets what she wants.

summary: on THAT scene with Sansa
body:
on THAT scene with Sansa

“Without Littlefinger and Ramsay and the rest, I would’ve stayed a little bird all my life.”


This quote has a lot of people talking. Granted it could’ve been worded better, but context is key.

Who is Sansa now? Is she the Sansa from season 1? No. The girl from season 2 or 3? Hardly. She has evolved much farther from those Sansas. Season 1 Sansa was a child, a little girl who loved handsome Knights in shining armour and beautiful princesses.

Season 8 Sansa knows that not all Knights wear shining armour, some wear dirty old leathers. They are not all handsome, some have very little (or broken) teeth, missing fingers, or disfiguring scars or deformities. They are CERTAINLY not all chivalrous either, there were plenty in the Kings Guard that proved that to her in King’s Landing. Season 8 Sansa knows that princesses may not be beautiful on the inside, despite their outward appearance. Perhaps they are not loving and kind to their subjects.

Season 8 Sansa is colder and harsher than her previous self. She’s seen much and done plenty (both willingly and forced) and has emerged in the way you’d expect. Years of abuse (from Joffrey onward really), torture, and rape have shaped her into who she is now. I echo Cersei’s words from Season 1, “You either play the Game of Thrones, or you die.” This “game” is not pretty or easy. It is dirty and tough. Only the strong survive this game. For Sansa, learning how to play the game was not like learning how to sew from her Septa. It was beaten into her, tortured into her, and yes, raped into her.

Granted, the scene needed better execution, but Sansa is looking at all of the negative in her life and forming a positive. Yes she was abused, yes she was tortured, yes she was raped…BUT SHE SURVIVED. She learned how to play the game the way EVERYONE in Westeros learns how to play it. No one who plays the game well has clean hands, no one. You may counter with Cersei probably not going through the same shit Sansa has endured and you’re right. But Cersei is a murderer, she has killed for her own gain. She has no remorse and she wasn’t prompted by anything other than her own jealousy.

In the scene in question, Sansa is talking with Sandor Clegane. He had just brought up how none of the things that have happened to her, would’ve happened if she had left with him. His voice and facial expression convey remorse and perhaps guilt at not forcing her to leave with him. But it can be taken in two ways.

1) if she had left with him, she would’ve avoided the torture, abuse, and rape. Sandor would’ve protected her from that. I believe he could have been successful given his track record with keeping Arya safe for as long as he could.

2) if she had left with him, it’s possible she’d have never learned to play the game well. He could be expressing that the person she is now wouldn’t exist if she had left with him.

There is a process my therapist has taught me about called Post Traumatic Growth. It’s something not everyone knows about. Post Traumatic Growth (or benefit finding) is “positive psychological change experienced as a result of adversity and other challenges in order to rise to a higher level of functioning.” I think that this is what Sansa is experiencing. It’s a healthy way of dealing with and overcoming trauma. It’s literally “looking on the bright side of things”.

People are coming back with “women don’t need tough experiences to be strong” and that’s true. But it’s also pretty narrow-minded. You’re not talking about someone who had never been through tough events. You’re talking about someone who had been a victim of abuse for YEARS. Someone who had been told she was a “stupid little girl” for YEARS! That takes a toll on someone’s self esteem and they start to believe it after a while. For Sansa, it took surviving and learning from these events to realise how strong she is. How strong she has always been, but hasn’t been able to see it.

Not everyone has to experience the worse life has to offer to be strong, but how dare you imply that horrible events can’t and don’t shape you into adulthood. That’s like telling a current victim of abuse that nothing they’ve endured will make an impact on their life.
